awd_titl_txt: Spin-orbitronic devices based on 2D Rashba Janus crystals as active materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Named after the two-faced Roman god one looking to the future while the other facing to the past, Janus crystals are new atomically thin materials having two different phases with different atomic arrangements. Theoretically these materials have extraordinary spintronic properties, to design and fabricate spin-based electronic devices instead of traditional charge-based transistors found in current computers. So far device fabrication has been restrictive due to limitations in sample preparation. This project aims to understand the spintronic properties of Janus layers and to integrate them into spin-based field-effect transistors and gating devices for next-generation electronic applications. The societal impacts will manifest through the introduction of a new generation of spintronic devices and lowering energy consumption in high-speed electronic devices. The project plans to integrate high school, undergraduate, and master’s students into an active research environment to create next-generation engineers and scientists. Career opportunities will be offered to underrepresented communities through research in an active laboratory environment and laboratory tours. Outreach activities include, involvement of K-12 students through ASU’s SCENE program.

This project focuses on studying the device physics of two-dimensional (2D) Janus transition metal dichalcogenide materials to demonstrate high-performance spin-FETs, tunable spin-texture devices, ballistic spin transport FETs by equalizing the Rashba and Dresselhaus effects by external gating. The initial experiments will involve synthesis of epitaxial and excitonic grade 2D Janus layers of MoSSe, WSSe, WSTe, and others with tunable Janus fields, followed by an understanding of Schottky junctions on 2D Janus semiconductors by using ohmic contact of a variety of metals. In addition, high-performance spin-FET devices will be fabricated with channel engineering insulation and optimized gate-stacks. Materials will be characterized, and devices will be optimized for process-structure-performance relations to achieve the highest spin-FET performance. Efforts will focus on establishing the foundations for spin precession and spin transport, gate-tunable spin textures, and spin FET operation on 2D Janus Rashba layers. The project will seek ways to achieve ballistic spin-transport and manipulation of spin-texture by suppressing spin relaxation through the Dresselhaus-Rashba crossover phenomena. The successful completion of this project will establish the fundamental device physics of 2D Janus layers, demonstrate spin-FETs based on these 2D Rashba Janus layers, and estswblish the basis for high-temperature scattering-resistant spin-FET operation through an interplay between Rashba-Dresselhaus terms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Our project focused on advancing the understanding and applications of 2D materials, specifically Janus transition-metal dichalcogenides, a unique class of materials with exciting properties. These materials possess built-in polarization fields that open up possibilities for groundbreaking applications in electronics, energy, and even medicine. The outcomes of our research have contributed to both scientific knowledge and practical innovations, with significant potential for future technological advancements.

Intellectual Merit: The primary intellectual contribution of our work lies in the synthesis, characterization, and understanding of Janus materials, specifically MoSSe, WSSe, and WSeS monolayers. We developed novel methods to fabricate high-quality, large-area Janus materials and performed in-depth analysis of their electronic and optical properties. Using techniques such as polarization-resolved spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy, we were able to identify and characterize the unique excitonic behaviors of these materials, including the neutral and charged exciton states. This understanding of their fundamental properties paves the way for future applications in high-performance electronic devices, particularly field-effect transistors (FETs).

We also explored the integration of Janus monolayers into vertical heterostructures, enabling doping control and fine-tuning of their electronic behavior. This work has helped define the device physics for Janus materials, shedding light on how to optimize their use in real-world applications. The insights gained from these experiments have opened new avenues for improving the performance and efficiency of emerging technologies, such as flexible electronics and optoelectronics.

Broader Impacts: Beyond advancing scientific knowledge, our project has had significant broader impacts in several areas, from education and outreach to commercial applications.

  1. Educational Outreach and Public Engagement: Our team has been deeply committed to engaging the public and inspiring the next generation of scientists, engineers, and innovators. Through our K-12 outreach efforts, including participation in events like ASU's Homecoming and the Holiday Cheer with the Engineer seminar, we have introduced over 1,000 students to the wonders of materials science and engineering. These activities not only foster curiosity but also provide early exposure to STEM fields, encouraging students to pursue careers in science and technology.

  2. Undergraduate Training and Workforce Development: We have created research opportunities for undergraduate students, giving them hands-on experience with cutting-edge techniques such as Raman spectroscopy, PL spectroscopy, and various deposition methods. This training helps students develop essential skills for their future careers, whether in research or industry. By mentoring these students, we have contributed to the development of a new generation of engineers and scientists equipped to tackle the challenges of tomorrow.

  3. Commercial Technology and Real-World Applications: Our research has also made significant strides in the realm of commercial technology. The insights into the Schottky barriers and FET performance of Janus materials have already influenced commercial collaborations, particularly with Applied Materials, which has provided further funding to explore their integration into real-world devices like FinFETs and GaAs-based transistors. This collaboration will likely accelerate the commercialization of these materials, impacting sectors such as electronics and semiconductors.

  4. Global Societal Impact: The potential applications of Janus materials extend far beyond electronics. With theoretical predictions for their use in hydrogen evolution reactions, solar cells, and piezoelectric devices, these materials hold promise for advancing clean energy solutions. Additionally, their unique polarization fields could be harnessed for novel medical devices and sensors, impacting healthcare and diagnostics. By contributing to sustainability efforts and offering new solutions in medicine, our work aims to address some of the most pressing global challenges.

In conclusion, our project has not only expanded the boundaries of materials science but also contributed to the development of educational resources, training for future scientists, and potential commercial technologies that could shape the future of electronics, energy, and healthcare. Through our interdisciplinary approach, we have helped bridge the gap between basic science and real-world applications, positioning Janus materials as a key player in the technologies of tomorrow.
